docs.title: 👋 Welcome to ArgoCD Pipeline Trigger
docs.text: A robust, secure, and GitOps-friendly solution to trigger ArgoCD syncs from CI/CD pipelines — complete with Slack/Telegram notifications, observability, Helm chart deployment, and Go-based tooling.

docs.title: ✨ What is this?
docs.text:
ArgoCD Pipeline Trigger is a modern DevOps tool that enables you to automatically sync ArgoCD apps whenever you merge a PR or trigger a CI/CD pipeline.

It includes: - ✅ Go CLI to trigger syncs manually or from pipelines - ✅ Webhook Receiver to automate triggers via HTTP - ✅ Notifications via Slack and Telegram - ✅ Exporter endpoint for Prometheus (/metrics) - ✅ Helm Chart for production-ready deployment

docs.title: 🔍 Who is it for?
docs.text:
• DevOps Engineers looking to automate ArgoCD
  • SREs seeking GitOps-safe syncs and notifications
  • Platform Engineers building GitHub → Argo pipelines
  • Engineering teams that need traceability and visibility in deploys

docs.title: 🧠 Why was it built?
docs.text: Most GitOps teams want to keep ArgoCD declarative — but also want control over when a sync happens. This project bridges CI with GitOps using a clean Go CLI, observable receiver, and best practices in infrastructure security and deployment.

docs.title: 📦 Features at a Glance
docs.text: Feature Description ✅ Go CLI argocd-sync syncs apps via ArgoCD API 🌐 Webhook Receiver HTTP endpoint for pipelines (GitHub, GitLab, etc.) 🔔 Notifications Slack + Telegram support with emoji and markdown 📈 Prometheus Metrics Built-in metrics endpoint + ServiceMonitor support 🎯 Helm Chart Deploy it anywhere with GitOps compatibility 🔐 Secure by Design Secrets via env/Helm, timeout, no default creds 🔬 Observability Full dashboard support via Grafana

docs.title: 🚀 Ready to try it?
docs.text:
Start with the Quickstart guide and deploy your first automated sync with notifications in under 2 minutes.

Looking to contribute? Check the Contributing guide.

docs.title: 🤝 Contributing to ArgoCD Pipeline Trigger
docs.text: Welcome! 🎉 First of all, thank you for considering contributing to this project. Whether you’re fixing bugs, adding new features, or improving documentation, we’re grateful for your help.

docs.title: 🧱 Project Philosophy
docs.text: ArgoCD Pipeline Trigger aims to be: - 💡 Simple: Easy to use and extend - 🔐 Secure: Safe by default - 📊 Observable: Prometheus and alert-ready - 🔁 GitOps-native: Ready for real CI/CD pipelines - 🧰 DevOps-first: Designed for real-world infra

docs.title: 1. Fork and Clone
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/argocd-pipeline-trigger.git
cd argocd-pipeline-trigger
git checkout -b my-feature

docs.title: 2. Run Locally
docs.text:
make build-webhook
make run-webhook

Or with Docker:

make docker-webhook

docs.title: 3. Add Your Changes
docs.text: Follow existing coding patterns, use idiomatic Go, and include comments when necessary.

docs.title: 4. Test Your Feature
docs.text:
go test ./...

Check with: 

make lint

docs.title: 5. Open Pull Request
docs.text: Please include: - A clear title and description - Screenshots or logs if applicable - Reference to any issues (e.g. Fixes #12)

docs.title: ✅ Code Guidelines
docs.text:
• Follow Effective Go
  • Format with go fmt
  • Use cobra for CLI

  • Secrets via env/Helm only

docs.title: 💬 Communication

docs.title: 🏗️ Architecture
docs.text: ArgoCD Pipeline Trigger follows a modular and extensible architecture with clear separation of responsibilities, security-first design, and GitOps-native patterns.

docs.title: 🔋 Components
docs.text: Component Description argocd-sync CLI Local command-line interface to trigger ArgoCD apps Webhook Receiver Listens to /sync POSTs, runs sync, emits metrics & notifs Notifier Slack/Telegram notification layer with custom formatter Helm Chart Production-ready deployment with observability and security

docs.title: 🔐 Security Boundaries
docs.text:
• Sync only happens on verified POST /sync
  • Tokens are never exposed — injected via Secrets
  • Distroless image and non-root runtime
  • Metrics and HTTP exposed on separate endpoints

docs.title: 🔎 Observability
docs.text:
• Prometheus /metrics endpoint with detailed counters and histograms
  • Grafana dashboard included in Helm chart
  • CI/CD traceability via webhook integration

docs.title: 🔄 Extensibility
docs.text:
The architecture is modular and can be extended with: - HMAC or mTLS verification (auth) - Custom notifiers (Discord, MS Teams, etc.) - App-specific sync rules or retries - Payload enrichment (commit SHA, PR number)

ArgoCD Pipeline Trigger was built to balance simplicity, observability, and flexibility — making it ideal for modern GitOps workflows.

docs.title: ⚙️ CLI: argocd-sync
docs.text: The CLI tool argocd-sync allows you to trigger ArgoCD application syncs directly from pipelines, scripts, or terminals.

docs.title: 🧪 Build locally
docs.text:
make build-trigger

Or build manually:

go build -o bin/argocd-sync .

docs.title: 🚀 Usage
docs.text:
./bin/argocd-sync sync \
  --app my-app \
  --server https://argocd.example.com \
  --username admin \
  --password secret \
  --insecure

docs.title: 📖 Flags
docs.text: Flag Description --app ArgoCD Application name --server ArgoCD API Server URL --username ArgoCD login username --password ArgoCD password or token --insecure Skip TLS verification (optional)

docs.title: 🔄 Use in CI/CD
docs.text:
GitHub Actions: 

- name: Sync app with ArgoCD
  run: ./bin/argocd-sync sync --app my-app --server https://argocd.example.com --username $ARGO_USER --password $ARGO_PASS

GitLab CI: 

sync:
  script:
    - ./bin/argocd-sync sync --app $CI_APP --server $ARGO_URL --username $ARGO_USER --password $ARGO_PASS

docs.title: 📁 Source
docs.text: See the implementation in cmd/sync.go.

docs.title: 🧭 Helm Deployment
docs.text: This project includes a production-ready Helm chart to deploy the webhook receiver and all its capabilities (metrics, secrets, notifications).

docs.title: 📁 Chart Location
docs.text: charts/webhook-receiver/

docs.title: 🚀 Install
docs.text:
helm upgrade --install webhook charts/webhook-receiver \
  --namespace default --create-namespace

docs.title: ⚙️ Values Overview
docs.text: Key Description notifications.slack.enabled Enable Slack notifier notifications.slack.webhookUrl Slack Webhook URL (via Secret) notifications.telegram.enabled Enable Telegram notifier notifications.telegram.botToken Bot Token (via Secret) notifications.telegram.chatId Chat ID (via Secret) metrics.enabled Enable Prometheus exporter metrics.path Path to metrics endpoint metrics.port Port for metrics exposure

docs.title: 🔐 Secrets Handling
docs.text:
We recommend creating Kubernetes secrets externally:

kubectl create secret generic webhook-receiver-secrets \
  --from-literal=telegramBotToken="<token>" \
  --from-literal=telegramChatId="<chat_id>"

docs.title: 📡 ServiceMonitor (Prometheus Operator)
docs.text:
Deploy manually or use helm template: 

kubectl apply -f charts/webhook-receiver/templates/servicemonitor.yaml

docs.title: 🎨 Grafana Dashboard
docs.text:
A dashboard is included via ConfigMap: 

kubectl apply -f charts/webhook-receiver/templates/grafana-dashboard.yaml

This allows dashboards to be versioned as code and loaded via sidecar.

docs.title: 🧪 Test Receiver
docs.text:
kubectl port-forward svc/webhook-receiver 8080:80

Then send a sync request: 

curl -X POST http://localhost:8080/sync -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d '{"app":"test-app"}'

The Helm chart is maintained under charts/ and accepts PRs for new features, values, and templates.

docs.title: 🔔 Integrations: Slack, Telegram, CI/CD
docs.text: ArgoCD Pipeline Trigger offers seamless integration with modern toolchains including CI/CD, Slack, and Telegram to improve visibility and automation.

docs.title: 🔧 Setup
docs.text:
1. Create an Incoming Webhook
  2. Store it in a Kubernetes secret:
kubectl create secret generic webhook-receiver-secrets \
  --from-literal=slackWebhookUrl="https://hooks.slack.com/services/..."
  1. Enable in values.yaml: 
    notifications:
  slack:
    enabled: true

docs.title: ✅ Message Example
docs.text:
✅ Sync Triggered
👨🏻‍💻 Giovanni Colognesi - ArgoCD Trigger
🔹 App: `my-app`
⏱️ Duration: `0.82s`

docs.title: 🔧 Setup
docs.text:
1. Talk to @BotFather
  2. Create a bot and get the token
  3. Start a conversation or group with the bot

  4. Find your chat ID: 

    curl https://api.telegram.org/bot<token>/getUpdates

  5. Create a Kubernetes secret: 

    kubectl create secret generic webhook-receiver-secrets \
  --from-literal=telegramBotToken="123:ABC" \
  --from-literal=telegramChatId="12345678"

  6. Enable in values.yaml: 

    notifications:
  telegram:
    enabled: true

docs.title: 🔁 CI/CD Pipelines
docs.text: Use curl to trigger the webhook after deploys:

docs.title: GitHub Actions
docs.text:
- name: Trigger ArgoCD sync
  run: |
    curl -X POST https://your-receiver/sync \
      -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
      -d '{"app":"my-app"}'

docs.title: GitLab CI
docs.text:
trigger:
  script:
    - curl -X POST https://receiver/sync -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d '{"app":"my-app"}'

docs.title: 🧪 Testing Notifications
docs.text:
Use the Go or Python scripts provided under scripts/:

go run scripts/test_notify_telegram.go
python3 scripts/test_webhook.py

These allow you to validate formatting and delivery without deploying to K8s.

docs.title: 📈 Metrics & Observability
docs.text: ArgoCD Pipeline Trigger includes native support for Prometheus metrics and Grafana dashboards — allowing teams to monitor sync events, performance, and failure rates.

docs.title: 🔌 Endpoint
docs.text:
A /metrics endpoint is exposed on the receiver:

GET /metrics

Use kubectl port-forward or a Kubernetes ServiceMonitor to scrape it.

docs.title: 📊 Metrics Available
docs.text: Metric Type Labels Description argocd_sync_total Counter app, status Total syncs triggered per app/status argocd_sync_duration_seconds Histogram app Duration of sync operation in seconds

docs.title: 🔍 Visualize with Grafana
docs.text:
A dashboard is provided as a ConfigMap and includes: - Total syncs (stat) - Sync duration per app (graph) - Sync rate and errors (table)

See: templates/grafana-dashboard.yaml

docs.title: 🧭 Prometheus Operator
docs.text:
The Helm chart also includes a ServiceMonitor:

apiVersion: monitoring.coreos.com/v1
kind: ServiceMonitor

Enable it with: 

kubectl apply -f charts/webhook-receiver/templates/servicemonitor.yaml

Or template via Helm.

docs.title: 🧠 Example Queries
docs.text:
sum(rate(argocd_sync_total[5m])) by (app)
rate(argocd_sync_total{status="failure"}[5m])
avg(argocd_sync_duration_seconds) by (app)

These queries can be used to build alerts or dashboards for: - Deployment frequency (DORA metric) - Failure rate - Time to deploy

For more, visit the Grafana page or use the included dashboard JSON.

docs.title: 🚀 Quickstart: ArgoCD Pipeline Trigger
docs.text: Get your Webhook Receiver up and running with Helm + Telegram integration in under 2 minutes.

docs.title: 🧭 Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Kubernetes cluster (Kind, Minikube, EKS, etc.)
  • Helm installed (v3+)
  • Telegram bot created (via @BotFather)

docs.title: 1. Clone the repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/giovanni-gava/argocd-pipeline-trigger.git
cd argocd-pipeline-trigger

docs.title: 2. Get your Telegram Chat ID
docs.text:
1. Create your bot with @BotFather
  2. Send a message to the bot
  3. Run:
curl -s "https://api.telegram.org/bot<TELEGRAM_BOT_TOKEN>/getUpdates"
  1. Copy the value of chat.id

docs.title: 3. Create the secret with your Telegram credentials
docs.text:
kubectl create secret generic webhook-receiver-secrets \
  --from-literal=telegramBotToken="<TELEGRAM_BOT_TOKEN>" \
  --from-literal=telegramChatId="<TELEGRAM_CHAT_ID>"

docs.title: 4. Install using Helm 🚀
docs.text:
helm upgrade --install webhook charts/webhook-receiver \
  --set notifications.telegram.enabled=true

docs.title: 5. Send a test Webhook
docs.text:
kubectl port-forward svc/webhook-receiver 8080:80

curl -X POST http://localhost:8080/sync \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"app": "demo-app"}'

docs.title: 📬 Expected Result
docs.text:
You should receive a message in Telegram:

✅ Sync Triggered
👨🏻‍💻 Giovanni Colognesi - ArgoCD Trigger
🔹 App: `demo-app`
⏱️ Duration: `XYZms`

docs.title: ✅ Done!
docs.text:
Your Webhook Receiver with metrics, logging, and notifications is now up and running.

Explore: - /metrics endpoint for Prometheus - Full Helm chart in charts/webhook-receiver - CI/CD pipeline integration via curl

Need help? Reach out on LinkedIn or open an issue on GitHub 💙

docs.title: 🌐 Webhook Receiver
docs.text: The Webhook Receiver is a lightweight, stateless HTTP service built in Go that listens for POST requests from CI/CD tools and triggers an ArgoCD sync operation.

docs.title: 🔧 How it works
docs.text:
1. CI merges a PR (e.g., GitHub/GitLab)
  2. CI sends a POST /sync to the Webhook Receiver
  3. Receiver runs argocd app sync <app> locally
  4. Duration and status are measured and exposed as Prometheus metrics
  5. A notification is sent to Slack/Telegram (optional)

docs.title: 🔐 Security Considerations
docs.text: Area Strategy Transport Use TLS (via ingress/controller) Auth Can be extended with token header (planned) Secrets Managed via Kubernetes Secret only Timeout Sync process has hard timeout (default: 10s) Rate limit Recommend external NGINX / Gateway limiters Input Strict JSON decoding and validation

docs.title: 📨 Payload format
docs.text:
{
  "app": "my-argocd-app"
}

If the app field is missing or malformed, the receiver responds with 400 Bad Request.

docs.title: ✅ Sample Response
docs.text:
HTTP/1.1 200 OK

ok

On error: 

HTTP/1.1 500 Internal Server Error

sync failed: app not found

docs.title: 🔁 Why not use ArgoCD webhooks directly?
docs.text: This project decouples sync automation from ArgoCD itself, allowing teams to: - Add metrics, alerts, dashboards - Control sync timing and conditions - Integrate notifications - Keep ArgoCD declarative while syncing on-demand

docs.title: 🔐 Security Best Practices
docs.text: ArgoCD Pipeline Trigger is designed with safety and production-readiness in mind. Below are the key practices and features included to support secure deployment and usage.

docs.title: ✅ Transport Security
docs.text:
• All traffic should be secured via TLS termination
  • Use Ingress controllers or service mesh (Istio, Linkerd) for HTTPS
  • Do not expose the webhook directly without protection

docs.title: 🔑 Secret Management
docs.text:
What How it's secured Slack Webhook URL Kubernetes Secret Telegram Bot Token Kubernetes Secret Telegram Chat ID Kubernetes Secret

Use sealed-secrets or SOPS for GitOps-friendly secret management.

docs.title: 🧱 Runtime Protections
docs.text:
• Webhook requests use timeouts (10s) to prevent long-running calls
  • --insecure flag in CLI is optional and off by default
  • Docker images are based on distroless to minimize attack surface
  • User runs as non-root (runAsUser: 65532)

docs.title: 🧪 Input Validation
docs.text:
• Payloads are parsed as strict JSON
  • Requests missing app or malformed will return 400 Bad Request
  • Future: extend with schema validation and OpenAPI

docs.title: 🚨 Rate Limiting (recommended)
docs.text:
Use a reverse proxy or ingress controller to add rate limiting:

nginx.ingress.kubernetes.io/limit-connections: "5"
nginx.ingress.kubernetes.io/limit-rpm: "30"

docs.title: 🧠 Suggested Enhancements (optional)
docs.text:
Feature Status Bearer token auth 🔜 planned HMAC validation 🔜 planned mTLS enforcement ❓ advanced

Security is an ongoing effort. Always review deployments, scan images with Trivy, and follow best practices from CNCF and OWASP.
